text: I work as a humanitarian aid worker
we're always traveling and that's how I
find a lot of the subjects some people
are more open and other people are a
little suspicious of what you're going
to do with the photographs fair shots
that there's a female in a crisis area
photographing people telling stories I
always like to photograph festivities
because you don't get to see a lot of
that and I am always looking for happy
stories I don't want it to be trauma all
the time children during the Eid
holidays they like to dress up very
colorfully they have groups that they
move around in it's a happy story in a
location where you don't get a lot of
happy stories how much of a shadow does
Boko Haram the militant group cast over
your town over your life well I would
say it's a it's very you know kind of
very saddening to say that that's what
we are known for and every day you
encounter a lot of sad stories we are
trying to bounce back what I would say
the vibe right now is one of struggle
we're trying to get back to what we knew
how dangerous is it for you for me
really I have thrown caution to the wind
and I feel like whatever it's meant to
happen will happen anywhere regardless
of where you are in the world so for me
I I have ultimately decided to just be
you know take a risk how do you want
people in the West seeing these pictures
to react what do you want them to think
about your town and about your people
I would like for them to see that we are
people living in a normal life they
would be shocked to see that the
struggles we face are similar to what
they face and I just want them to see
the resilience the fact that you have
adversity but you are thriving amidst
the adversity
